facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 130 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 130 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 21, 1958 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 31 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1958 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 31 of 1958. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants.

facts.text: Maharaja Sir Rajendra Prakash Bahadur Maharaja of Sirmur and others carried on business in partnership under the firm name Messrs. Jagatsons International Corporation at New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Maharaja Sir Rajendra Prakash Bahadur Maharaja of Sirmur, Maharani Mandalsa Kumari Debi Rajmata of Sirmur, Maharani Premlata Debi of Chhota Udaipur, Maiyan Sahiba Sheba Kumari Debi of Jharipani, Major Rao Raja Sirendra Singh, Jagat Pershad, Shib Chander Kumar, Praduman Kumar and Dayawati Rani carried on business in partnership

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 Ramnarain Private Ltd. instituted Summary Suit No. 162 of 1957 against the firm on Original Side of Bombay High Court claiming Rs. 1,96,831.58 N.P.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, Ramnarain  Private  Ltd. instituted Summary Suit No. 162 of 1957 against Messrs. Jagatsons International Corporation on the Orginal Side of the Bombay High Court claiming a money decree for Rs. 1,96,831-58 N.P.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 and the firm entered into agreement dated September 26, 1956 whereby respondent No. 1 agreed to provide finance to the firm.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted on the allegation that respondent No. 1 and the firm had entered into an agreement in writing dated September 26, 1956, whereby respondent No. 1 agreed to provide finance to the firm,

facts.text: Sum of Rs. 1,96,831.58 N.P. was due to respondent No. 1 from the firm due to dealings under the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: as a result of the dealings under the agreement a sum of Rs. 1,96,831.58 N.P. was due to respondent No. 1 from the firm,

facts.text: Consent of Central Government not obtained for suit though Maharaja of Sirmur is Ruler under s.87B CPC.

anchor.surface_text: and in view of the breaches of the agreement by the firm, the agreement has stood terminated. The companysent of the Central Government to the institution of the suit was number obtained, though the Maharaja of Sirmur is a Ruler of the former Indian State within the meaning of s. 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Summons served on Shib Chander Kumar as partner.

anchor.surface_text: The summons of the suit was served oil Shib Chander Kumar as a partner of the firm and as a person having the companytrol or management of the partnership business.

facts.text: On July 15, 1957, firm admitted liability and applied for installments; court passed decree for Rs. 1,89,643.98 N.P. and interest payable in installments.

anchor.surface_text: On July 15, 1957, at the hearing of the summons for judgment taken out by respondent No. 1, the firm admitted its liability as claimed in the plaint and applied for installments, and the Court passed a decree for Rs. 1.89,643.98 N.P. and further interest, and directed that the decretal amount would be payable in certain instalments.

facts.text: Firm committed defaults in payment of installments.

anchor.surface_text: The firm companymitted defaults in payment of the instalments payable under the decree.

facts.text: On December 13, 1957, respondent No. 1 filed application under O.21 r.50(2) CPC for leave to execute decree against specific partners: Maharani Mandalsa Kumari Debi etc.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1957. respondent No. 1 filed an application under 0. 21 r. 50 2  of the Code of Civil Procedure for leave to execute the decree against Maharani Mandalsa Kumari Debi,  2  Maharani Premlata Debi,  3  Maiyan Sahiba Sheba Kumari Debi,  4  Major Rao Raja Sirendra Singh,  5  Jagat Pershad.  6  Praduman Kumar and  7  Dayawati Rani

facts.text: Opposite parties filed affidavit alleging no consent under s.86 CPC, and that Jagat Pershad and Shib Chander Kumar entered agreement fraudulently without authority and concealed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite parties to the application filed an affidavit alleging  1  that the suit and all proceedings therein were incompetent in the absence of the requisite companysent of the Central Government under s. 86 of the Code of Civil Procedure  2  Jagat Pershad and Shib Chander Kumar entered into the agreement dated September 26, 1956 and utilised the moneys received under it in fraud of the other partners and without their authority,

facts.text: By order dated March 18, 1958, single Judge rejected contentions and allowed application under O.21 r.50(2).

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated March 18, 1958, a learned single Judge of the High Court rejected all the companytentions in the affidavit, and allowed the application under 0. 21, r. 50 2  of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Appeal by appellants Maharani Mandalsa etc. dismissed by High Court Bench on November 21, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal preferred by appellants, Maharani Mandalsa Kumari Debi, Maharani Premlata Debi, Major Rao Raja Sirendra Singh and Maiyan Sahiba Sheba Kumari Debi was dismissed by a Bench,of the High Court on November 21, 1958.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal under certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants number appeal to this Court under a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellants contended suit incompetent without consent under s.86 read with s.87B CPC against Maharaja.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants Mr. D. N. Mukherjee companytended that  1  the suit against the firm of Jagatsons International Corporation was a suit against all its partners and in the absence of the requisite companysent under s. 86 read with s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure,

facts.text: Court held decree against Maharaja of Sirmur is nullity due to lack of consent.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the suit so far as it was one against the Maharaja of Sirmur was incompetent and the decree against the firm so far as it is a decree against him personally was a nullity.

facts.text: Court held decree against firm other than Maharaja is valid and executable under O.21 r.50.

anchor.surface_text: But the suit against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur was companypetent, and a decree companyld be passed against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur, and such a decree companyld be executed against the partnership property and against the other partners

facts.text: Affidavit does not sufficiently raise plea of collusion or fraud against respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit filed on behalf of the appellants does number sufficiently raise a plea that the decree was the result of any companylusion, fraud or the like. The affidavit incorrectly assumes that the decree passed on admission of the appearing partner,

facts.text: Appellants were partners of the firm at the time cause of action accrued.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were admittedly partners of the firm of Jagatsons International Corporation at the time when the cause of action accrued.

The consent of the Central Government to the institution of the suit was number obtained, though the Maharaja of Sirmur is a Ruler of the former Indian State within the meaning of s. 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: Whether the suit against the firm of Jagatsons International Corporation was a suit against all its partners and, in the absence of the requisite consent under s. 86 read with s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure, incompetent against the Maharaja of Sirmur with the decree against him being a nullity

holdings.text: the suit so far as it was one against the Maharaja of Sirmur was incompetent and the decree against the firm so far as it is a decree against him personally was a nullity

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the suit so far as it was one against the Maharaja of Sirmur was incompetent and the decree against the firm so far as it is a decree against him personally was a nullity. The first contention of Mr. Mukherjee is. therefore, sound and should be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit against firm under O.30 is really against all partners; s.86 r/w s.87B bars suit against Ruler without Central Govt consent; legal fiction of O.30 does not override substantive bar

holdings.text: the suit against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur was competent, and a decree could be passed against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur, and such a decree could be executed against the partnership property and against the other partners by following the procedure of 0. 21, r. 50 of the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: But the suit against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur was competent, and a decree could be passed against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur, and such a decree could be executed against the partnership property and against the other partners by following the procedure of 0. 21, r. 50 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to cases of infant/dead partners where decree valid excluding incapable partner; O.30 allows suit/decree against firm excluding barred partner; executable under O.21 r.50

holdings.text: A suit by or in the name of a firm is thus really a suit by or in the name of all its partners... So also a suit against the firm is really a suit against all the partners of the firm

anchor.surface_text: A suit by or in the name of a firm is thus really a suit by or in the name of all its partners, see Rodriguez v. Speyer Brothers  4 , Purushottam Umedbai Co. V. M s Manilal Sons  3  at pp. 991, 993, 995. So also a suit against the firm is really  1  1956 S.C.R. 156,162.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.30 r.1 provides legal fiction for convenience; firm not separate entity per Partnership Act s.4 and precedents; fiction limited, does not create new entity

holdings.text: the second contention of Mr. Mukherjee should be rejected... The application of respondent No. 1 under 0. 21, r. 50 2  for leave to execute the decree against the other partners is, therefore maintainable

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of Mr. Mukherjee is. therefore, sound and should be accepted. But we think that the second contention of Mr. Mukherjee should be rejected. Beyond doubt, in a normal case where all the partners of a firm are capable of being sued...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects argument that lack of consent vitiates entire decree; decree amendable to exclude Maharaja; valid against others per analogies

holdings.text: what defences may be raised by a respondent to an application under 0. 21, r. 50 2  of the Code of Civil Procedure. The law on this point is now well-settled... primarily the question to try would be whether the person against whom the decree is sought to be executed was a partner of the firm, when the cause of action accrued. but he may question the decree on the ground of collusion, fraud or the like
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Gambhir Mal: limited to partnership at accrual, collusion/fraud on decree, nullity, special protection; no re-trial of merits or inter-partner disputes

holdings.text: The affidavit filed on behalf of the appellants does not sufficiently raise a plea that the decree was the result of any collusion, fraud or the like
holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation of fraud/collusion against decree-holder (respondent No.1); inter-partner fraud not relevant defence under O.21 r.50(2)

holdings.text: the respondent may also defend the application on the ground that the decree sought to be executed against him is a nullity
holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends Gambhir Mal to include nullity as defence under O.21 r.50(2)

holdings.text: Nor is the decree against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur a nullity
holdings.reasoning_summary: Only null against Maharaja; valid against others

outcome.relief_summary: First contention accepted (decree nullity against Maharaja of Sirmur); second contention rejected (decree valid against other partners, executable under O.21 r.50); third contention rejected (no other defences like fraud or merits allowable in O.21 r.50(2) proceedings)
directions: Decree should be suitably amended so as to make it a decree against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur
Application under O.21 r.50(2) for leave to execute against other partners is maintainable

anchor.surface_text: But the suit against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur was competent, and a decree could be passed against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur, and such a decree could be executed against the partnership property and against the other partners by following the procedure of 0. 21, r. 50 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

But the suit against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur was competent, and a decree could be passed against the firm other than the Maharaja of Sirmur, and such a decree could be executed against the partnership property and against the other partners by following the procedure of 0. 21, r. 50 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

A suit by or in the name of a firm is thus really a suit by or in the name of all its partners, see Rodriguez v. Speyer Brothers  4 , Purushottam Umedbai Co. V. M s Manilal Sons  3  at pp. 991, 993, 995. So also a suit against the firm is really  1  1956 S.C.R. 156,162.
